articleContent.title: Chord: Dominant 7th in F (Shape: G)
articleContent.content:
# Dominant 7th Chord in F (Shape: G)

The Dominant 7th chord is a four-note chord consisting of a major triad with an added minor seventh interval. In the key of F, using the G shape, the Dominant 7th chord is formed by playing G, B, D, and F notes. This chord is often used in a variety of musical styles, including jazz, blues, funk, and rock music.

## Notes and Intervals
- G (Root)
- B (Major 3rd)
- D (Perfect 5th)
- F (Minor 7th)

## Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7th chord in the key of F (played with the G shape) adds tension and a sense of movement that typically resolves back to the tonic chord, creating a strong sense of musical resolution. It has a rich and bluesy sound that can add depth and complexity to a musical composition.

## Songs
1. "Stormy Monday" by T-Bone Walker
2. "Route 66" by Bobby Troup
3. "Superstition" by Stevie Wonder
